I am a Korean, I am proud of myself as a Korean. Now, Korea is very peaceful and can not find any social chaos at all.

I want tell you how the infection rate is falling down in Korea is as follows;
1. The most advanced democratic system.
=> Never Korean government have controlled people's freedom , never closed social door. and never closed airport.

the government has never controlled or ignored their criticisms. According to their criticism,
our government is collecting and correcting their policy again and again.

But Korean government is reacting seriously against even one person's infection and the center for disease
control of Korea is sending SMS alert message to each person through Mobile phone like that infected person
of No.1 or...No.30 COVID was a certain of building, a certain of restaurant or what metro etc. and the authorities
gives final report that "disinfecting operation is completed and the infected person is now under isolation in a hospital"
and people near by him or her are under isolation in their house. If the people violate the rule related to the self isolation,
they get a serious penalty from our government.


2. The most advanced medical system.
=> We pay 3~8% medical insurance depending on incomes from all labor or business as the duty,
All people who do social activity must pay medical insurance. So, all Korean people even thought they are rich
or poor gets medical treatment with very very low price.
If we get a cold, we can get the medical treatment in the hospital at less than 5 dollars. and drugs are just one or
two dollars in the pharmacy.
In case of COVID, if someone else get a cold and take diagnosis for that, the person pays USD100 in case of
no COVID infection, however if the person gets infection diagnosis, the USD100 is returned from the public medical
insurance authorities.
However, if the infected person gets medical treatment in the hospital, the medical fee is really low or mostly free
by the public medical insurance.


3. The most advanced citizenship and mobile networking.

if we are not lazy, we can buy masks without any problem with USD1.

to have stocks.
there are also many mobile application to help buying mask and inform the infected people's stay in Korea. Never we have a panic
on internet service as well.

Korean people are really responsible to every of their duties, for that reason, there are many things to occupy industrial top rank

It is plain as the nose on your face, why this expert didn't say it, I don't know.
(1) There are areas in the USA that look like they don't have a big problem,
THAT is because they have way less population (density) and they are probably
practicing social distancing and they aren't fully tested. They probably have
more infections but know it. Just like in the North East, we thought the
infection wasn't high, UNTIL we get testing moving. If you say go back to work,
you could raise the rates of infection and negate the effects of social
distancing this harming the people and hampering the containment of the virus.
(2) If you look around the world, it takes 3 to 4 weeks for a sick person to
recover, we haven't been infected long enough (and tested) to see and track
recovered cases. (3) The ONLY people who need to be at work are the healthcare
workers and support services, police, supply chain for food and medical etc.
THEY need every PPE they can get so they are protected, PERIOD, the states
should not have to ask, the FEDS should deliver ASAP no questions asked, the
healthcare system is working OVERTIME to save our lives. (4) If we don't have
the patience (fortitude) to stick to the EASIEST way of defeating the virus
(social distancing) then we are idiots. Once the number of infections level off
and start to decline ONLY THEN can we project a time to return carefully to
work. Looking around the world to see how long that has taken, Chins, S Korea,
Iran, Italy, etc. That data will give us the timeline. (4) It is OBVIOUS that
social distancing IS the STRONGEST weapon we have to combat this and any other
virus. On its own the virus will probably die off in 2 to 3 weeks if it can't
spread to another host (person). (5) Listen to the professional EXPERTS, not
politicians or news anchors. This information (REAL) information is what the
talking heads should be spreading. (6) Our politicians - leaders should be
backing the experts, telling the people what the government can and will do to
get the people of the USA through this situation we weren't prepared for. The
CARE ACT IS a very strong attempt to do just that! Be patience, be smart, be
calm, don't be greedy at the food and pharmacy stores. Support each other, we
are or should be a team in the crisis. We don't need BS from anyone, we need a
solid real, smart plan to achieve a goal. Citizen of the USA

The most worrisome fact is that in Korea, socially important people, certified, celebrities, and professional sports players were not exposed to the coronavirus, but in the United States and Europe, socially famous people were exposed to the coronavirus. This means that the U.S. and European governments still haven't figured out the path of the coronavirus. In Korea, on the other hand, the possibility of socially important people going to places with high risk of exposure to the coronavirus or contacting people infected with the coronavirus is close to zero. This is because the government actively grasped the information of people exposed to the coronavirus. (The reason for 9,000 Korona patients in Korea despite the efforts of the Korean government is that the foolish cult members with the coronavirus lied to the government.) When we talk about Korea's quarantine system, many people are concerned about whether we can release the personal information of patients with coronavirus to society. There's actually no answer. What is clear, however, is that many people in Korea support the Korean government's decision. All we can do is for individuals to give up some freedom for the sake of the vast majority of safety, while at the same time society gives thanks and encouragement to individuals infected with the coronavirus. Whether this policy is an infringement or a concession depends solely on the thinking of those who look at the matter. someone might think that Koreans follow national policies well because they still don't know the importance of freedom and individual human rights. I'm pretty sure it's about supply and demand (Economics 101). In South Korea, they already wear masks quite a bit because of pollution and some wear it for fashion as well. Masks are a norm so there was already a market with people willing to buy it, so they'll already have more masks. In America, very few people wore masks before the outbreak. Few people wanted them so there were few in stock to be sold. Also, it's about the response to the pandemic. In America, many downplayed the virus in the early stages and didn't stock up on masks or testing kits. Therefore, once Americans started needing masks, there already was a shortage. South Korea was prepared before the worst of the pandemic hit and were able to flatten the curve while the US is trying to catch up as it gets worse.

One lesson to all westerners: wear mask in public 100% all the time! Look at China's 31 other Provinces, Singapore, Japan, S. Korea, Thailand, the Philippines, etc., very near to the epicenter of the outbreak with high tourism travels between countries and yet the virus spread is controlled and not that high compared to the West. Climate and humidity are not the big factor as Beijing, S. Korea among other regions is also colder like the west BUT the common denominator is:
- public wearing of masks

This covid-19 is a respiratory disease and primarily transmitted via respiratory droplets and saliva. Everytime a person speaks fine saliva droplets are ejected, nevermind sneezing and coughing. An asymptomatic person unknowingly spreads the virus this way, by just mere talking inside subway, elevator, bus, airplane, close rooms, etc. Those droplets can be inhaled or ingested by unsuspecting person closeby. Another route is when those droplets land on surfaces such as handles, food items, packaging, tables, etc. Unsuspecting person can catch that virus via direct contact on contaminated surfaces. Westerners are taught washing of hands is more important to prevent catching the virus. However, wearing mask is a good preventive measure from catching the virus through inhalation or ingestion. It also prevents the ejection of the virus from the mouth (saliva droplets) in asymptomatic and infected person. It also prevents someone from unnecessarily touching the nose and mouth from unwashed hands in public. People normally touch their faces subconsciously.

If you are in a sparse area, without mask still ok. Afterall you'd need a lot of masks if this epidemic is gonna last a few mths. I think in East Asia, people are already wearing them even in normal situation when they are sick or against pollution would just find it a normal extension of their lives but in western countries, it'd take a lot of convincing, as you can see even enforcers like police officers aren't wearing. The South Korean healthcare system is run by the Ministry of Health and Welfare and is free to all citizens at the point of delivery. The system is funded by a compulsory National Health Insurance Scheme that covers 97% of the population. So if they want to get tested, they will get it. This is an important factor,  We need to identify problem areas and that can only be determined by testing as many people as possible. Again, we are not advising people to take test unless they have symptoms. Our healthcare system may not be capable of handling all confirmed patients, especially at this growing rate and at this stage. Overall, we are doing our best but I just want to point out that our healthcare system isn't designed to follow the same path.

First, let me tell you that I'm South Korean.

Some people argue that if you have symptoms, you're staying at home without going out, and why are you wearing a mask?¬†But the scary thing about this covid-19 is that it has no symptoms like fever or coughing, but it's possible it's positive.¬†So we recommend that not only the medical staff but also the public wear masks.¬†Then I can prevent it from passing on to others when I'm sick without even realizing it.¬†Then again, some people will argue, taking issue with the lack of masks.¬†

Yes, it is.¬†In fact, the current amount of masks in Korea is not enough to be distributed to all Koreans.¬†That is why the Korean government is taking the approach of purchasing all goods produced by various mask factories and distributing them to the public through pharmacies.¬†And people are donating free of charge to medical institutions if they are judged to have a rather generous amount of masks (All surgical masks produced in Korea are distributed to medical institutions). This is how the mask market is now in Korea.

In conclusion, wearing a mask is one of the fundamental ways to solve this situation.¬†Thank you for reading. I hope you have a safe and happy day.

@ Karen: I've been harping on this from DAY ONE! Excerpted from a previous comment of mine elsewhere:

With the potential 3-hour in-air lifespan, and the fact that, depending on air currents... or maybe just the lack thereof... small enough particles can remain airborne for almost that long, someone could sneeze, walk away, and you could come into that "airspace"... whether it was stationary or had shifted... even half an hour later and STILL be exposed. The carrier could be miles away by that time. Rather than being close to the PERSON, think of it as entering the AIRSPACE they may have contaminated. "Six feet" isn't much cushion.

I can't see a virus with the naked eye, but I have certainly LARGER particles appear as if they could continue to float in the air INDEFINITELY; not FALLING, but RISING as I've observed them.

Meanwhile, in the U.S., we're being told: "you don't need a mask, because, if you wear one, this means a health care worker won't have one and will likely get infected and possibly die". WTF? SEE! No matter how many times health care personnel WASH THEIR HANDS, it will NOT protect them from aspirating the AIRBORNE virus!

Telling "civilians" that they don't need a mask is akin to saying civilians shouldn't own firearms because they "might shoot the wrong person in a panic"... we are ALL "regular" people, civilians, law enforcement, AND health-care personnel!
